channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: At Okinawa Protest, Thousands Call for Removal of U.S. Bases
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Naha, the capital of the Japanese prefecture of Okinawa, protesting the United States military presence on the island. Organizers said that 65,000 people attended.
item.description: Organizers said the protest, billed as a memorial for a woman who was killed, was the largest demonstration against the United States’ presence in two decades.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: E.U. Countries Warn Britain: You’ll Pay if You Leave Us
item.media:description: Supporters of Britain’s leaving the European Union campaigned near Parliament in London last week.
item.description: If they vote to depart the bloc, the British should expect an unforgiving response from Brussels, which is wary of other nations following suit.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Anti-Immigration Poster Denounced by a Top ‘Brexit’ Advocate
item.media:description: A poster circulated by Nigel Farage’s U.K. Independence Party was condemned Sunday, days after lawmaker Jo Cox was killed.
item.description: Michael Gove, Britain’s justice secretary, said a campaign effort by Nigel Farage’s U.K. Independence Party “was the wrong thing to do.”
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Memo From Spain: Venezuela Casts a Long Shadow on Elections in Spain
item.media:description: Albert Rivera, the leader of Spain’s center-right Ciudadanos party, arriving in Venezuela in May at the invitation of opponents of President Nicolás Maduro.
item.description: Leaders of the leftist Podemos party once advised the government of Hugo Chávez in Venezuela, a country whose economic collapse is an issue in national elections next Sunday.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Venezuelans Ransack Stores as Hunger Grips the Nation
item.description: A nation anxiously searches for ways to feed itself, as the economic collapse of recent years has left it unable to produce or import sufficient food.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Israel Approves Additional Funding for Settlements in West Bank
item.media:description: Israeli troops demolishing unlicensed sheds belonging to Palestinians near Yatta in the West Bank on Sunday.
item.description: The approximately $20 million in financing underlined Israel’s strengthened right-wing orientation and raised the ire of political opponents and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Leaks of Answers Before Egypt’s National Exams Embarrass Government
item.description: One test was canceled, and the Education Ministry, along with the police and military officers who guard the exams, faced a wave of criticism.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: A War of Brothers in Iraq: ‘I Will Kill Him With My Own Hands’
item.media:description: Iraqi government forces and allies advanced through Falluja on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Haidar Mohammed Ali/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: For Iraqi Sunnis, the struggle to retake Falluja from the Islamic State underscores the personal nature of war: a conflict of sons and brothers, nephews and neighbors.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and FALIH HASSAN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Hong Kong Bookseller Finds Associates Challenging His Account of Detention
item.media:description: Lam Wing-kee in Hong Kong, on Sunday, three days after saying that he was abducted by mainland police in October, held in solitary confinement and denied legal representation. Former colleagues and a woman claiming to be his girlfriend have disavowed his claims.
item.description: Lam Wing-kee publicly described months in mainland Chinese custody, but former colleagues and a woman who says she is his girlfriend have disputed what he said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: U.S. Carriers Sail in Western Pacific, Hoping China Takes Notice
item.media:description: The aircraft carriers John C. Stennis, left, and Ronald Reagan, right, and other warships on Saturday in the Philippine Sea.
item.description: Ships carried out exercises in the Philippine Sea as a show of strength before an international court’s ruling on China’s claims in the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: China’s Last Wild River Carries Conflicting Environmental Hopes
item.media:description: The Nu River at Bingzhongluo, China. Over the years, various government agencies and state companies have proposed building dams along the 1,700-mile river and harnessing its power.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: With global temperatures rising, can a nation afford to protect a pristine waterway and forgo the building of dams as an alternative to burning coal?
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Decades Later, Sickness Among Airmen After a Hydrogen Bomb Accident
item.media:description: John H. Garman was in the United States Air Force when, in 1966, a fully loaded B-52 bomber on a Cold War nuclear patrol collided with a refueling jet high over the Spanish coast, freeing four hydrogen bombs that went tumbling toward a coastal farming village called Palomares. Mr. Garman was among those who were first on the scene of the crash.
item.media:credit: Raymond McCrea Jones for The New York Times
item.description: The Air Force says that there was no harmful radiation at the crash site, but interviews with dozens of men and details from declassified documents disagree.
item.dc:creator: DAVE PHILIPPS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Newcomer Beats Renzi's Candidate in Rome Mayoral Runoff
item.description: An anti-establishment newcomer, capitalizing on anger over political corruption and deteriorating city services, trounced Premier Matteo Renzi's candidate in Rome's mayoral runoff.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Commitment to Class Conflict Drives Leader of French Labor Unrest
item.media:description: Police officers subdue a demonstrator during a labor protest on Tuesday in Paris.
item.description: Philippe Martinez, whose views were shaped by longtime ties to the Communist Party, has refused to back down in his union’s fight against a proposed labor law.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: U.S. Tells Russia of ‘Strong Concerns’ About Strikes on Syrian Rebels
item.media:description: Russia’s defense minister, Sergei Shoigu, second from the left in the back row, visited the Russian air base in Syria on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Vadim Savitsky/Russian Defense Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.description: In a videoconference with Russian counterparts, American defense officials discussed an attack on U.S.-backed forces who are fighting the Islamic State and who should be covered by a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Lives Still in Limbo, One Year After Southeast Asia Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Mohammed Salim, a Rohingya man in a refugee camp in Aceh Province, Indonesia. Mr. Mohammed, 24, was aboard a crowded fishing boat that journalists found adrift last year in the Andaman Sea.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: While most of the migrants from Myanmar and Bangladesh have been sent home or smuggled elsewhere, many still languish in refugee camps and detention centers.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Crossfire Kills Bangladesh Assault Suspect in Custody, Police Say
item.description: Ghulam Faijullaha Fahim, who was being held in an attack on a teacher, was hit by crossfire when officers took him to help capture his associates, a police chief said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Regardless of ‘Brexit’ Vote, Experts Say, E.U. Must Rethink Status Quo
item.media:description: A Union Jack fluttering beside European Union flags at union headquarters in Brussels.
item.description: Tribulations for the euro, a debt standoff with Greece and a flawed approach to migration all inflamed the angry nationalism spreading across the Continent and Britain.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Belgium Says It Prevented a Terror Attack on Soccer Fans
item.description: Police raids interrupted a plot against fans gathering in Brussels to watch a telecast of a match between the Belgian national team and Ireland, officials said.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Suspect in British Lawmaker’s Killing: ‘My Name Is Death to Traitors’
item.media:description: A court artist sketch of Thomas Mair, the suspect in the killing of Jo Cox, a member of Parliament. Mr. Mair appeared in court on Saturday.
item.description: Thomas Mair, 52, who has been charged with murdering Jo Cox, a member of Parliament, made the remark during a brief court appearance Saturday.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Shifting Attention to Mediterranean, NATO Fights Internal Dissent
item.media:description: British paratroopers jumped from a C-130 Hercules plane during an alliance training exercise near Torun, Poland, this month.
item.description: Beyond confronting Russia in the east, the alliance is facing an array of challenges on its southern flank, including terrorism and uncontrolled migration.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Leaving Past Behind, Northern Ireland Unified Behind Its Team
item.media:description: Northern Ireland fans applauded their team after Sunday’s loss in the European Championships.
item.description: A boy who watched the biggest soccer match in his country’s history in 1982 is now the coach. He hopes to replicate the team’s success in the European Championships.
item.dc:creator: JAMES MONTAGUE

item.title: What in the World: A Magnet for Titanic Fans in an Unexpected Graveyard
item.media:description: The Fairview Lawn Cemetery in Halifax, Nova Scotia, on April 15, 2012, the 100th anniversary of the sinking of the Titanic.
item.description: Fairview Lawn Cemetery holds more victims of the world’s best-known shipwreck than any other place — including the grave of a certain J. Dawson.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: Rise at 11? China’s Single Time Zone Means Keeping Odd Hours
item.description: Some days, the sun doesn’t come up until 10 a.m. in Urumqi, where clocks are set to Beijing time despite being 2,000 miles to the west.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: The Deeper Meaning of Mexico’s Giant Speed Bumps
item.media:description: A well-worn tope in Mexico City, scarred by the undercarriages of countless cars.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: Suspension-killing wonders called topes, which crop up on highways and back streets alike, are a means of enforcing speed control and civility, and cannot be avoided.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: 11 Syrian Refugees Reported Killed by Turkish Border Guards
item.description: Most, including at least three children, were from the same extended family and were shot near the crossing at the town of Jisr al-Shoughour, Syrian activists and a monitoring group said.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Opinion: Drought Selfies and Drought Suicides
item.media:description: A boy from a rural village stricken by drought standing guard over his family’s water containers at a camp in Mumbai.
item.description: India's government cares little for the plight of the rural poor.
item.dc:creator: SONIA FALEIRO

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte: After Orlando
item.description: Donald Trump is assiduous about word choice.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Mr. Modi, Don't Patent Cow Urine
item.description: India’s innovative patent system has brought cheap generic drugs to millions. Now it’s under threat — because the Hindu right is obsessed with cows.
item.dc:creator: ACHAL PRABHALA and SUDHIR KRISHNASWAMY

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
